G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court under G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 223, § 2, as the events giving rise to this complaint occurred within Worcester County and the rental property is located within the Worcester District Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court under G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 223, § 2, as the events giving rise to this complaint occurred within Worcester County and the rental property is located within the Worcester District Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord shall not directly or indirectly interfere with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly held that the presence of vermin, unsanitary conditions, or persistent defects that impair the tenant’s ability to use the premises are violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in the context of unsanitary housing conditions, and holds that a landlord’s failure to maintain sanitary, watertight premises, resulting in repeated flooding, constitutes interference with quiet enjoyment. The court links liability under § 14 to violation of the duty to maintain sanitary conditions, and describes § 14 as part of a body of statutes addressing “unsanitary conditions,” thereby treating such conditions as a basis for quiet enjoyment violations. Although the facts involve flooding rather than vermin specifically, the reasoning clearly extends to unsanitary conditions and persistent defects that impair use of the premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 belongs to a body of statutes establishing tenants’ remedies against landlords who fail to provide safe and sanitary housing. … The objectives of these statutes go beyond deterrence of intentional wrongdoing; unsanitary conditions in an apartment cause harm to the occupants whether the landlord has acted intentionally, negligently, or innocently. … Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly held that the presence of vermin, unsanitary conditions, or persistent defects that impair the tenant’s ability to use the premises are violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on whether a statutory lead paint violation, by itself, constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and holds that it does not absent at least negligent conduct. While the court cites other quiet-enjoyment cases involving defects in premises, this case itself does not address vermin, unsanitary conditions, or persistent habitability defects, nor does it articulate any rule specifically about those conditions. It therefore does not establish or reaffirm the specific proposition claimed, and at most only indirectly references other authority that might do so.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: "We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so)."

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly held that the presence of vermin, unsanitary conditions, or persistent defects that impair the tenant’s ability to use the premises are violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: This case concerns noise from a lounge operated on nearby premises and whether that noise, which the landlord could control, constituted a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction. It does not discuss vermin, unsanitary conditions, or persistent physical defects, nor does it establish any rule specifically tying those types of conditions to violations of quiet enjoyment. While it supports the broader principle that substantial interferences with habitability can breach quiet enjoyment, it does not support the narrower, specific proposition stated.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge.”

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly held that the presence of vermin, unsanitary conditions, or persistent defects that impair the tenant’s ability to use the premises are violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment and holds that serious interference with tenants’ ability to use common areas (here, due to criminal drug activity) can constitute a breach, but it does not address vermin, unsanitary conditions, or persistent physical defects. The court is dealing with security and third‑party criminal conduct, not with habitability problems like vermin or filth, and it expressly cabined those issues to the warranty of habitability discussion. Thus this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition about vermin and unsanitary conditions as violations of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly held that the presence of vermin, unsanitary conditions, or persistent defects that impair the tenant’s ability to use the premises are violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: The opinion involves severe code violations, including infestation by cockroaches and rodents and lack of heat, but the court’s analysis is framed in terms of breach of the implied warranty of habitability and G.L. c. 93A, not the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court does not discuss or hold that vermin, unsanitary conditions, or persistent defects constitute violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment; indeed, the trial judge dismissed the quiet enjoyment counterclaim to avoid cumulative damages, and the SJC does not analyze that issue. Thus, this case does not provide authority for the specific quiet‑enjoyment proposition stated.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).relevant_excerpt: "After a trial, a judge of the Housing Court found in favor of Gonzalez on all of her counterclaims and awarded her damages under c. 186, treble damages under c. 93A (for the intentional infliction of emotional distress and violation of the warranty of habitability)... To avoid awarding cumulative damages, however, the judge dismissed all but the retaliation and c. 93A counterclaims…. After his view, the judge made express findings… (8) the apartment was infested with cockroaches and rodents."

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly held that the presence of vermin, unsanitary conditions, or persistent defects that impair the tenant’s ability to use the premises are violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The case deals with loss of heat and hot water as breaches of the implied warranty of habitability and the timing of rent abatement; it does not address vermin, unsanitary conditions, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The opinion repeatedly frames the issue in terms of the warranty of habitability and sanitary code violations, not quiet enjoyment, and contains no discussion of vermin or persistent defects in that specific doctrinal context. Thus it cannot be cited as authority for the stated proposition about violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Superior Court judge found there was insufficient evidence to conclude that the landlord acted intentionally, negligently, or in bad faith. He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. The judge ruled further that the tenant is allowed to abate the rent from the date the landlord had notice of the breach of the warranty of habitability.… A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable.”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly held that the presence of vermin, unsanitary conditions, or persistent defects that impair the tenant’s ability to use the premises are violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion mentions several State Sanitary Code violations in the tenant’s apartment, including mice and ants, and acknowledges a breach of the warranty of habitability, but it does not analyze or decide a claim for breach of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court frames the defects in terms of habitability and rent abatement, and it says many conditions had only minimal impact on use and enjoyment, without articulating any general rule that vermin or unsanitary conditions constitute a violation of quiet enjoyment. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific quiet enjoyment proposition stated.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: “Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property.2 The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs. … Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability…”

Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 363 Mass. 359.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly held that the presence of vermin, unsanitary conditions, or persistent defects that impair the tenant’s ability to use the premises are violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 363 Mass. 359.case_name: Board of Appeals of Hanover v. Housing Appeals Comm.
Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 363 Mass. 359.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns the validity and operation of Massachusetts General Laws c. 40B (the anti‑exclusionary zoning statute) and the powers of local zoning boards and the Housing Appeals Committee. It does not involve landlord‑tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or conditions such as vermin or unsanitary premises. Therefore, it does not support the proposition about vermin or unsanitary conditions constituting a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 363 Mass. 359.relevant_excerpt:
We hold that c. 774 confers on boards of appeals and the Housing Appeals Committee the power to override local “requirements and regulations,” including zoning ordinances or by-laws, which are not “consistent with local needs.”

...

Chapter 774 represents the Legislature’s use of its own zoning powers to respond to this problem.

Lipsitt v. Plaud, 466 Mass. 240 (2013).proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly held that the presence of vermin, unsanitary conditions, or persistent defects that impair the tenant’s ability to use the premises are violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Lipsitt v. Plaud, 466 Mass. 240 (2013).support_reasoning: The opinion in Lipsitt v. Plaud concerns whether the Massachusetts Wage Act preempts common-law contract and quasi-contract claims for unpaid wages, and secondarily addresses veil piercing. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, quiet enjoyment, vermin, unsanitary conditions, or defects in residential premises. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition regarding violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment based on such conditions.
Lipsitt v. Plaud, 466 Mass. 240 (2013).relevant_excerpt: Because the Legislature did not intend the Wage Act to be the exclusive remedy for the recovery of unpaid wages, Lipsitt’s common-law claims for breach of contract and quantum meruit should not have been dismissed. Further, because Lipsitt pleaded sufficient facts to state a claim against Plaud on a theory of piercing the corporate veil — or, in the alternative, should have been allowed to amend his complaint in that regard — Plaud should not have been dismissed as a defendant.

Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004)
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have repeatedly held that the presence of vermin, unsanitary conditions, or persistent defects that impair the tenant’s ability to use the premises are violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that a serious, persistent defect (here, a long‑standing ventilation problem causing moisture, foul odors, and ultimately a fire) constituted a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment because it seriously interfered with the tenancy and substantially impaired the value of the premises. While this case specifically discusses ventilation and not vermin, it treats insect infestation and similar unsanitary conditions as serious sanitary code violations that impair health and safety, and it links such significant conditions to both habitability and quiet enjoyment. Thus it supports the broader proposition that persistent, health‑impairing defects can violate quiet enjoyment, though the vermin aspect is more inferential than explicit.
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The implied covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees tenants the right to be free from ‘serious’ interferences with their tenancies. See G. L. c. 186, § 14; Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); Ianello v. Court Mgmt. Corp., 400 Mass. 321, 323-324 (1987). A landlord violates G. L. c. 186, § 14, when its ‘acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises.’ Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789 (1994). … On these facts … we think that the judge was required to find a serious interference with the tenancy and substantial impairment of the character and value of the leased premises.”

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127A.proposition: The State Sanitary Code, adopted under G.L. c. 111, § 127A, requires landlords to maintain rental dwellings free from infestation, 105 C.M.R. § 410.550, and to correct any conditions endangering the health, safety, or welfare of occupants.

105 C.M.R. \u00a7 410.550.proposition: The State Sanitary Code, adopted under G.L. c. 111, § 127A, requires landlords to maintain rental dwellings free from infestation, 105 C.M.R. § 410.550, and to correct any conditions endangering the health, safety, or welfare of occupants.
